docs.lead_paragraph: Bryan Caplan, an economist at George Mason, is the author of "Selfish Reasons to Have More Kids," which will be released this week. Mr. Caplan doesn't believe everyone should have a lot of children. But he does say many parents and future parents should consider having more children than they are currently planning.

headline.main: The Case for Having More Kids

docs.abstract: Bryan Caplan, an economist at George Mason University, talks about his new book, "Selfish Reasons to Have More Kids."

docs.lead_paragraph: A debate about Makena, a costly drug to prevent premature birth, revolves around the struggle between manufacturers and the government over who is best equipped to safeguard the nation’s drug supply.

headline.seo: Pregnancy Drug Makena Is Latest Skirmish in Old F.D.A. Battle
headline.main: Drugs’ Cost and Safety Fuel a Fight
headline.print_headline: Drugs’ Cost And Safety Fuel a Fight

docs.lead_paragraph: Giovanni Romano, a native of New York, is the chef at the Backroom Bistro in Sioux Center, Iowa. His cooking has won over local residents, who keep coming back for more.

docs.lead_paragraph: Under last year’s overhaul, Medicaid rolls are expected to grow drastically, but budget woes have states reducing payments to caregivers.

headline.main: Cuts Leave Patients With Medicaid Cards, but No Specialist to See
headline.print_headline: Cuts Leave Patients With Medicaid Cards, but No Specialist to See

docs.snippet: Under last year’s overhaul, Medicaid rolls are expected to grow drastically, but budget woes have states reducing payments to caregivers.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Jennifer Campbell is 39 years old and is 26 weeks pregnant with her second son. Her first, who is now two-and-a-half, was born prematurely at 29 weeks (28 weeks, six days to be exact), and her high-risk obstetrician is using the tools available to keep that from happening again. One of those tools is a drug called "17P," which, until recently, cost $10 for each weekly injection. But a few weeks ago the name of the drug changed to Makena and the price went up to more than $1,500 per shot, which would have brought the cost to $30,000 for Ms. Campbell's four-month treatment, she explained to me in an e-mail.
docs.abstract: How a drug that last month was $10 per injection, suddenly rose to $1500 for that same injection, then just as suddenly fell to $690?
docs.snippet: How a drug that last month was $10 per injection, suddenly rose to $1500 for that same injection, then just as suddenly fell to $690?
